### About me

I am a postgraduate student at the London School of Economics. My primary interests is the use of econometrics and quantitative methods to study political phenomena. I also am a current intern at the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP).

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
## My Education

I am currently a student at the London School of Economics, studying for a Masters of Science in Political Economics. My coursework mainly focuses around statistics/econometrics and game theory/mathematical modelling.

Prior to my MSc, I completed a BSc (Hons) in Politics from King's College London, receiving First Class Honours (US Equivalent: Summa Cum Laude). My undergraduate degree was focused on Public Policy and Quantitative Methods in Political Science.

During my undergraduate degree, I also took summer courses in Data Science + Machine Learning and Accounting at the London School of Economics.

I did my high school education in the United States at Canyon Crest Academy.

Fun fact: I received an offer to do my Master's at Cambridge (MPhil Politics and International Studies). I made the difficult choice of turning this down for LSE, as my interests lie in more quantitative approaches to political science, rather than international relations.
:::

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
## My Work Experience

My work experience includes two internships with the United Nations Development Programme.

My first internship was with the Foresight Team within the Regional Bureau of Asia and the Pacific. There, I contributed to a publication on the potential effects of climate migration on Pakistan and Vietnam, and helped draft potential policy solutions. I, along with my colleagues, organised an online consultation with local stakeholders in Pakistan and Vietnam to facilitate inclusive policy-making.

My second internship was with the inclusive growth team of the Bureau for Programme and Policy Support. There, I contributed to a publication on UNDP's effectiveness in promoting the Samoa Plan of Action for Small Islands and Developing States (SIDS). I worked on a database of "best practices" regarding UNDP social protection programmes. I also completed mapping work on extractive industries for COP29.
:::

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
## My Personal Life

I am originally from San Diego, California, but I have now spent the last 3 years of my life in London.

Outside of my academic interests and work, my hobbies include watching Basketball and Football, playing the Violin and Piano, and studying linguistics and creating constructed languages.
:::

## Rubian, Renata, Dajna Sorenson, Rishi Chakraborty, Kevin Li, and Jade Cooper. “SIDS: Looking Back and Forward – Accelerating Action in the Next 10 Years.” *United Nations Development Programme*, (May 2024).

<br />

I co-authored this report while working with the Inclusive Growth team in the Bureau of Policy and Programme Support at the United Nations Development Programme. This report investigates and reports the impact that the UNDP's programmes and policies had on the development of small island and developing states between 2014 and 2024.

<https://www.undp.org/publications/sids-looking-back-and-forward>
